title: requiring an alias module returns an empty object
body:
Hi,

I don't know if this is really a bug, but at least this is an issue for me...

When giving an alias `Myapp` for my main script `src/index.js`, ie:

``` sh
./node_modules/.bin/browserify -r ./src/index.js:Myapp
```

then, if I try to `require('Myapp')` somewhere else, it returns an empty object `{}` rather than my expected `Myapp` constructor

NB : `Myapp` constructor is correctly exported in `src/index.js`, ie:

``` js
function Myapp() {
  alert('hi new myapp instance!')
}

exports.Myapp = Myapp;
module.exports = Myapp;
```

Can you confirm it's a bug ?

Thank you

title: Sourcemaps comments are *not* placed at the end of the file when using 'standalone' option
body: The source map spec says that the source map url comment must be ["a line at the end of the source"](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1U1RGAehQwRypUTovF1KRlpiOFze0b-_2gc6fAH0KY0k/edit). Browserify is including it wrapped inside the function. This is breaking [source-map-resolve](https://github.com/lydell/source-map-resolve), and likely breaks other things as well.

title: Standalone option causes errors not to emit correctly
body: browserify does not emit errors correctly when I use the `standalone` option, and instead it throws an error (for example, when a require call cannot be resolved). This causes a gulp watch task to stop. I came up with a workaround for gulp (https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/issues/440), but it would be better if the `standalone` option emitted errors the same way as `bundle()` without the `standalone` option.

title: Recursive package.json browser key required
body:
We use Component at work but I prefer Browserify at home. I want to be able to use the same code I write at work at home and at work. The Component guys have a bunch of great components on which our "components" depend. Because components are named differently in the component and npm ecosystems the dependencies of the components which we use (e.g. component-event is a dependency of component-delegate) try to require a component using the component ecosystem name and fail. 

[npmcomponent](https://github.com/airportyh/npmcomponentï»¿) rewrites popular components to work with node (but our own aren't so lucky). 

Browserify's package.json browser key half solves this problem. Using the following code makes the defined components work in Browserify.

```
"browser": {
    "event": "component-event",
    "delegate": "component-delegate",
    "emitter": "component-emitter"
}
```

However, many of these components have their own dependencies on other components which will fail to install because of the name difference. Utilising the browser key recursively in _each_ component/package would make component packages work.

title: Source maps corrupt/invalid and I'm not sure why...
body:
I've got browserify running on a couple of bundles. It is basically one big bundle and a bunch of smaller ones that take advantage of `external` for modules already in the big bundle. Everything was working well and then I started using more node packaged modules (project isn't using NodeJS so browserify is our gateway to node modules) and made a number of other changes and realized that Chrome was no longer reporting the correct file and line number for debugging.

What is the best way to figure out what is invalid in the source map? I see `exorcist` mentioned in the README here:

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify#external-source-maps

I'll try that just to see what happens. I'll also take a look at `convet-source-maps` here:

https://github.com/thlorenz/convert-source-map

Any suggestions you or anyone else has are very welcome.

title: browserify source maps omit the 'version' property
body:
As far as I can tell, and the only thing that makes sense is that, the 'version' property is a required property of a sourcemap file. Browserify omits it. [mozilla/source-map](https://github.com/mozilla/source-map) throws the error `"version" is a required argument.` when a browserify sourcemap is passed into it. 

Browserify uses version 2, am I right? This shouldn't be a difficult thing to add.

title: browserify hanging when used as grunt task
body:
I'm new to browserify, and I'm trying to convert a quite large js project using browserify, but before converting any code I decided to test it against simple examples that resemble what I will be doing in the real app code.

Everything was working fine, but suddenly my grunt task started hanging after issuing the 'browserify' command. After hours of tests (reverting my changes, using grunt-browserify, grunt-shell, node ChildProcess exec, bash script) I started reverting browserify to old versions and when I got to the version 3.40.2 it started working again.

Looking into the diff I found that a change in the `index.js` file was causing my grunt task (using any method to execute it) to hang indefinitely... the following is the link to the commit:

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/commit/74989d7686090bb7a30c50de810d36f58bbcd348#index-js-P4

I've reverted the line back to how it was in 3.40.2 and the problem was fixed. So I don't know if I'm doing something wrong or if this is a bug. Bellow is my sample configuration

`sample.html`

``` html
<html>
<head>...</head>
<body>
   <script>
      myObject = {};
      myObject.name = 'test';
   </script>
   <script src="path/to/my-bundle.js"></script>
</body>
</html>
```

`expose-my-object.js`

``` js
module.exports = window.myObject;
```

`packages.json`

``` json
{
  "name": "mobile",
  "description": "some description",
  "version": "0.0.1",

  "browser": {
    "myobject": "./path/to/file/expose-my-object.js"
  },

  "devDependencies": {
    "browserify": "3.44.2"
  }
}
```

`browserify command`

```
browserify -r myobject -o path/to/my-bundle.js
```

title: Allow specifying an entry point's extension (when passing in a stream)
Allow opts.entries to include buffers
body:
Currently `opts.entries` can include filenames or streams, but not buffers.

If I happen to already have the buffer in memory, it would be good if I could pass it to browserify as an entry point.

``` javascript
var b = browserify({entries: [someBuffer]});
```

title: allow arrays in require and external
body:
Which makes it easier to bundle all your `node_modules` automatically like this:

https://gist.github.com/spacepluk/11396649

title: Add stack trace to bin error output.
body:
On the command-line, it is currently rather difficult to discover where/why an error is being generated as the output error message does not include a trace trace. Perhaps this was included at some point in the past and has disappeared with security changes to the Error object. Current error messages can originate deep inside the module hierarchy and/or not be easily greppable due to generic/concatenated messages.
### Example Output
#### Before

```
> ./bin/cmd.js -t ./test/bin_tr_error/tr.js ./test/bin_tr_error/main.js
Error: there was error
>
```
#### After

``` bash
> ./bin/cmd.js -t ./test/bin_tr_error/tr.js ./test/bin_tr_error/main.js
Error: there was error
    at Stream.end (/Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/test/bin_tr_error/tr.js:9:28)
    at _end (/Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/node_modules/through/index.js:65:9)
    at Stream.stream.end (/Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/node_modules/through/index.js:74:5)
    at f (/Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:230:19)
    at makeTransform (/Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:296:20)
    at ap (/Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:215:13)
    at applyTransforms (/Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:232:11)
    at /Users/timoxley/Projects/libs/node-browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:178:17
    at fs.js:266:14
    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:107:15)
>
```

amended: fixed some 2 space indentation.

Related to #707.

title: Max stack errors
body:
Using the latest browserify I get `Max stack exceeded` errors when trying to compile browserify-fs (mafintosh/browserify-fs#1). If I downgrade browserify to 3.32.1 everything works as expected.

Any ideas whats causing this?

title: exclude missing modules when ignoreMissing is set
body:
This makes so that `require` calls to missing modules now throw instead of returning `{}` when the `--ignore-missing` flag is set, as reported on https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/733.

I believe this behavior better matches the node.js semantics.

I noticed though that through the API there's a consistent distinction between `ignore` and `exclude`. Perhaps it's a better idea to create a `--exclude-missing` flag to make this distinction fully orthogonal across the API?

title: Requiring a missing module in a build made with `--ignore-missing` returns an empty object instead of throwing
body:
I've been experimenting with the `--ignore-missing` flag and I noticed this strange behavior:

Whenever the code attempts to require a missing module, instead of throwing the `require()` call actually returns an empty `{}` object.

This only happens for missing modules actually referenced by your code. If I use the JS console to require some missing module that's not referenced by the code manually, it throws as expected.

As it is, the current behavior of "ignore missing" doesn't quite match node's semantics, and is more like "replace missing with blank", which is not as useful IMO.

title: Browserify can hang on certain modules.
body:
Browserify could hang when attempting to bundle certain modules. github is one such module I found. More details in this gist:

```
$ npm install github
npm http GET https://registry.npmjs.org/github
npm http 200 https://registry.npmjs.org/github
npm http GET https://registry.npmjs.org/github/-/github-0.1.16.tgz
npm http 200 https://registry.npmjs.org/github/-/github-0.1.16.tgz
github@0.1.16 node_modules/github
$ browserify node_modules/github
```

The browserify process hangs indefinitely at this point.

title: pass dir as second argument to packageFilter
body: Pass second arg to packageFilter, follow-thru to changes introduced to module-deps in https://github.com/substack/module-deps/commit/a82197229eb00ec8aefa95d12c7f8f00569062fa

title: End output with semicolon
body:
I am in an environment where sometimes the output of browserify is concatenated with other outputs (some being output of browserify, some being other JavaScript). The lack of a terminating semicolon on the output from browserify is causing errors.

Is this okay or do we want to make this an option or push this concern off to consumers?

title: Allow b.external() to accept an array of files
body: I have several external dependencies I don't want to include in the main bundle; would be great if b.external() took an array of files/modules to leave out.

Fixes #724

```
$ tree
```

```
module.exports = 'a';
```

```
var a = require('a');

console.log('a is "a": ', a === 'a');
```

I can use `NODE_PATH` so that `require('a')` works:

```
$ NODE_PATH=/tmp/browserify-list-issue/assets node specs/a_spec.js
a is "a":  true
```

```
$ NODE_PATH=/tmp/browserify-list-issue/assets browserify specs/a_spec.js
(function e(t,n,r){function s(o,u){if(!n[o]){if(!t[o]){var a=typeof require=="function"&&require;if(!u&&a)return a(o,!0);if(i)return i(o,!0);throw new Error("Cannot find module '"+o+"'")}var f=n[o]={exports:{}};t[o][0].call(f.exports,function(e){var n=t[o][1][e];return s(n?n:e)},f,f.exports,e,t,n,r)}return n[o].exports}var i=typeof require=="function"&&require;for(var o=0;o<r.length;o++)s(r[o]);return s})({1:[function(require,module,exports){
var a = require('a');

console.log('a is "a": ', a === 'a');
```

title: Browserify --list fails after 3.36.1
body:
Given `a.js`:

```
var _ = require('underscore'),
    b = require('./b');

console.log(_.extend(b, {bad: false}));
```

And `b.js`:

```
module.exports = { good: true };
```

With browserify 3.33.1:

```
$ browserify --version
3.33.1
$ cat a.js | browserify --list
/private/tmp/x/b.js
/private/tmp/x/fake_38fdbcb.js
/private/tmp/x/node_modules/underscore/underscore.js
```

With browserify 3.39.0:

```
$ browserify --version
3.39.0
$ cat a.js | browserify --list

events.js:72
        throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
              ^
TypeError: Invalid non-string/buffer chunk
```

title: Piping to browserify with --require produces different results versus giving filename for input
body:
Piping a file to browserify when using the `--require` command line option produces different output from passing the filename as a command line argument. Here is the example in which code from `a.js` is omitted from the bundle when it is piped:

https://github.com/cymen/browserify-piped-input-issue

```
browserify --require underscore a.js > browserify-direct.js
cat a.js | browserify --require underscore > browserify-piped.js
```

I am using 3.39.0 (global).

Am I using it wrong? My reason to use `--require` is to get browserify to give underscore a "magic name" like `ZKusGn` so that on another file (stream), I can use `--external underscore` and it'll use the "magic name" to pull it in (we're talking about a key within `module` that points to underscore I assume).

I need to do it via a pipe because I'm in the Rails asset pipeline with Sprockets giving me sprocketized-output (so things like `//= require` processed). I can't simply add the filename to the command line because it would be pre-sprocketized if read direct from the filesystem.

title: Piping to browserify broken
body: In 3.33.1, `cat example.js | browserify --list` produces a list of dependencies. In 3.9.0, it returns nothing.

title: __dirname seems to be incorrectly formatted in bundles
Full zlib module support
body: I implemented a [replacement module](https://github.com/devongovett/browserify-zlib) for the current zlib module being used by browserify that supports the full Node zlib API. It uses the actual JS zlib code from Node, and passes Node's zlib tests by basically implementing the C++ binding that Node uses on top of [pako](https://github.com/nodeca/pako), which is a direct port of zlib to JS.  This means that the full API is implemented (including streaming, async, sync, etc.), the API and behavior exactly matches Node, and because pako is a direct port of zlib, the output is binary identical to the output produced by Node's zlib module.  Also, pako is way faster than the zlib library being used by the current module (see benchmarks on their repo compared to imaya).  The only things not implemented yet are the `params` method and the `dictionary` option because pako doesn't have the underlying methods for those yet, but I hope to write patches for those soon.  Let me know what you think!

title: node 0.6 and 0.8
body:
It looks like the latest browserify (via covert) breaks on node 0.6 and 0.8, although it works in node 0.4. I'm seeing Travis failures on many modules. Example: https://travis-ci.org/caolan/forms/jobs/22476731

It seems like testing tools need to work on as wide a version range as possible - can this be fixed?

title: test the same way we build
body: aka remove watchify

title: Browserify doesn't seem to like `require('..')`
body:
I'm not sure if this is supported or not, but it works in node, so I'd hope it would work in Browserify.

Anyway, I tracked down a bug to a line requiring a module using `require('..')` where there was a file named index.js in the parent directory.

If I change it to be `require('../')`, everything works fine.

title: opt.builtins cleanup (proposed)
body:
Current implementation breaks if `opt.builtins` is set to anything other than `false` (not falsey)
or an object similar to lib/builtins.js, and only actually _does
anything_ in the `false` case.

The current documentaion describes `opt.builtins` as "set[ting] the list of builtins to use", 
which sounds to me like it would be a whitelist array of builtin names
as strings, but the CLI defaults it
to `true`, but always sets it to `false` or `undefined` when calling the
API.

Given all this, and an admittedly incomplete knowledge of the use cases
on my part, I propose the following spec for `opt.builtins`, which this
pull request implements.

| `opt.builtins` | Behavior |
| --- | --- |
| `false` | exclude all builtins (current behavior) |
| `true` | no effect (currently breaks) |
| `["builtinname",...]` | exclude all builtins not named in the array (empty array behavior matches `false`) |

The `true` option, while not strictly necessary, provides symmetry as
  well as allowing the use of a boolean defined elsewhere to control
simple inclusion/exclusion of builtins (eg gutil.env.node)

Any other value (object, number,..) will have no effect, effectively matching the `true`
behavior. For some reason, deciding what they would do was just one
  assumption too many for me. :-)

I've modified the `no_builtins` test to also check the empty array case,
but I need some direction on how to write the tests for the whitelist
cases.

Any feedback would be appreciated, especially on how to
build those tests.

body: Fixing some typos in the readme. Thanks!

title: Update umd dependency
body: This fixes a few issues with some AMD/RequireJS loaders for --standalone

title: Don't load same module multiple times if resolved from differnt paths
body:
There was an optimization which compared the dependency paths instead of
the hashes if the same modules where compared multiple times. This was
not taking into account that a module might be referenced from multiple
paths.

Removing the optimization solves the issue and does not seem to cause
any noticable performance drops.
- Fixes issue #692

title: Fix syntax highlighting of code block in readme
body:
Changed:
![old highlighting](https://i.cloudup.com/HGGsnHf6OQ.png)
To:
![new highlighting](https://i.cloudup.com/OAGK5yyKFL.png)

title: Browserify output is not always the same, even from the same machine
body: I created a simple project and readme at https://github.com/boblauer/BrowserifyExample so anyone can reproduce the issue.  A large percent of the time, Browserify spits out the same file, but occasionally the order of the the bundle's entries will be different.  I tried to figure out what was going on myself, but I was getting nowhere fast.

title: Update to derequire@~0.8.0
body: The older version was still using esprima-six, whereas >=0.8 are using esprima-fb :)

title: Update bin/cmd to use through2.
body: Just did a fresh install of browserify and noticed it was looking for `through` rather than `through2` in `bin/cmd.js`, which is defined in `package.json`.

title: Pass transforms to module-deps in deps
body: So we don't have to duplicate them in a call to deps. Fixes #600. Fixes #697.

title: Reducing the size of browserify when installed
body:
Right now, browserify's sitting at over 50MB to install through npm. Though when running it through disc, it appears under 2MB of that is actually getting required:

![screen shot 2014-03-27 at 2 33 20 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/569817/2533561/b10e063a-b560-11e3-85cf-b2dc5184f296.png)

I ran a fresh install through DaisyDisk:

![screen shot 2014-03-27 at 2 35 23 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/569817/2533569/e0d75c72-b560-11e3-9e67-0909eb953a7d.png)

And there's a few modules including more test code than browserify itself needs to run, e.g. the url package alone being the worst offender at 20MB because punycode's got a copy of requirejs in there somewhere.

It might be worth looking into this for the sake of reducing `npm install` time and saving on disk space. I know I have tons of projects with local copies of browserify and it's starting to take its toll :)

Thoughts?

title: Absolute paths in bundle source when referencing globals
body:
When I use a global like `process`, browserify will use absolute paths for key names in the generated source, e.g. `'/Users/my-username/path/to/my-project/node_modules/grunt-browserify/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/insert-module-globals/node_modules/process/browser.js'`. I created an example case at https://github.com/christophercliff/grunt-browserify/tree/paths-experiment.

Is there a workaround to avoid exposing the absolute path?

cc https://github.com/jmreidy/grunt-browserify/issues/157

title: Fix bug with --global-transform command line argument
body: Previously the `{ global: true }` opts being passed by `--global-transform` was being lost and thus `--global transform` was behaving the same as a normal `--transform`.

title: External require of midi results in "process.versions is undefined" in bundle.js
body:
Hi. I am trying to browserify node-midi from justinlatimer. I installed the npm package in my directory, then ran browserify -r midi > bundle.js. I created a bare bones html file that includes the following:

```
<script src="bundle.js"></script>
<script>
      var midi = require('midi');
      var input = new midi.input();
      console.log(input.getPortName(0)); // simple test to see if browserified midi works
</script>
```

This results in: "TypeError: process.versions is undefined" at bundle.js 90:

```
var fs = require('fs')
  , path = require('path')
  , join = path.join
  , dirname = path.dirname
  , exists = fs.existsSync || path.existsSync
  , defaults = {
        arrow: process.env.NODE_BINDINGS_ARROW || ' Ã¢â â '
      , compiled: process.env.NODE_BINDINGS_COMPILED_DIR || 'compiled'
      , platform: process.platform
      , arch: process.arch
      , version: process.versions.node // RIGHT HERE
      , bindings: 'bindings.node'
      , try: [
          // node-gyp's linked version in the "build" dir
          [ 'module_root', 'build', 'bindings' ]
          // node-waf and gyp_addon (a.k.a node-gyp)
        , [ 'module_root', 'build', 'Debug', 'bindings' ]
        , [ 'module_root', 'build', 'Release', 'bindings' ]
          // Debug files, for development (legacy behavior, remove for node v0.9)
        , [ 'module_root', 'out', 'Debug', 'bindings' ]
        , [ 'module_root', 'Debug', 'bindings' ]
          // Release files, but manually compiled (legacy behavior, remove for node v0.9)
        , [ 'module_root', 'out', 'Release', 'bindings' ]
        , [ 'module_root', 'Release', 'bindings' ]
          // Legacy from node-waf, node <= 0.4.x
        , [ 'module_root', 'build', 'default', 'bindings' ]
          // Production "Release" buildtype binary (meh...)
        , [ 'module_root', 'compiled', 'version', 'platform', 'arch', 'bindings' ]
        ]
    }
```

Any ideas? 

Thank you

title: Error: ENOENT, open 'tls' while resolving "tls"
Option for browserify to not touch external files
body:
I use a build tool that automatically infers build dependencies by intercepting reads and writes. To improve build times, I split my application into several bundles, using -x to externalize. To my surprise, browserify still reads from these files, causing my build tool to recompile for no reason. Presumably this is to calculate the IDs for each module? (My intuition would be that browserify would simply ignore any dependency marked external.)

For now I've hacked around it by requiring a computed string: `require('./my-' + 'path.js')`. But it would be cool if I didn't have to do this.

title: Performance
body:
Hi,

Firstly, resolved paths were not cached, so I added a fix for that (1ea7c1e). Although the performance win for this one is quite minuscule.

Secondly -- derequire. Now THAT's a serious bottleneck. I suggest to make it optional, which is what 37d434c implements. In my case the bundle performance went from 13-ish seconds to 2 seconds with derequire disabled. And I never had any issues in our huge code-base with derequire off.

Cheers,
M.

title: basedir not resolving in dependencies
body:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but setting `basedir`, I expect to be able to require relatively to this folder, inside the dependencies.

I have a very simple example that I cannot make work, given the following file structure:

```
js/app.js
js/src/models/Person.js
js/src/views/PersonView.js
```

(Note: `app.js` requires `PersonView.js`)

I would expect to be able to require `Person.js` from within `PersonView.js` like so:

```
var Person = require('./src/models/Person');
```

Instead of the normal method, relatively to `process.cwd()`:

```
var Person = require('../models/Person');
```

But running `bundle`...

```
var b = browserify('./app', {basedir: './js'});
b.bundle().pipe(process.stdout);
```

... I get the following error:

```
Error: module "./src/models/Person" not found from "/Users/..some path.../js/src/views/PersonView.js"
```

Any hint/help would be much appreciated.

title: Comprehension Error with array containing 'for'
body:
Hello!

I'm using [SugarJS](https://github.com/andrewplummer/Sugar/) with Browserify, and whenever I compile I get this problem:

```
SyntaxError: Line 7626: Comprehension Error while parsing /Users/dan/...etc.../node_modules/sugar/release/sugar-full.development.js
```

I did some investigation and found that it's due to the word 'for' being used on line 7626, equivalent to [7674 in the most recent commit](https://github.com/andrewplummer/Sugar/blob/master/release/sugar-full.development.js#L7674) which includes the word 'for' in an array, like so:

``` javascript
  Downcased = [
    'and', 'or', 'nor', 'a', 'an', 'the', 'so', 'but', 'to', 'of', 'at',
    'by', 'from', 'into', 'on', 'onto', 'off', 'out', 'in', 'over',
    'with', 'for'
  ];
```

I suppose this probably has something to do with it being a reserved word, but I'm not sure. If you remove all the surrounding lines and literally just have a file with that array, it's fine.

I think this may be a problem with Browserify. I rolled back to 3.24.7 since I found a similar issue on [Swig's page](https://github.com/paularmstrong/swig/issues/422), and I found the compile to work just fine.

So, seems a bit dodgy to me. Any thoughts?

``` js
var b = ['if'];
```

```
Error: Parsing file /Users/pierre/src/temp/browserify-bug.js: Line 2: Unexpected string
```

title: Using transforms from js api?
Obfuscate module paths in require function
body:
After compiling with browserify I run the output through an uglifier. Naturally the paths to the required moduls stay intact as they are strings and cannot be minified.

```
{forms:a("./ui/forms"),placeholder:a("./ui/placeholder")},d=
{ajax:a("./utils/ajax"),css:a("./utils/css"),events:a("./utils/events"),
jsonp:a("./utils/jsonp"),ready:a("./utils/ready"),root:a("./utils/root"),
selector:a("./utils/selector")},e={};b.exports={ui:c,utils:d,features:e}},
{"./ui/forms":2,"./ui/placeholder":3,"./utils/ajax":4,"./utils/css":5,
"./utils/events":6,"./utils/jsonp":7,"./utils/ready":8,"./utils/root":9,
"./utils/selector":10}
```

I did not fully comprehend how browserify runs its magic, but for my understanding those "paths" can be replaced by random strings as they are not actual path to existing files, but simplay keys to the designated modules. WouldnÂ´t it be nice to also obfuscate those strings as they exploit my internal folder structure?

There is a bug in [concat-stream](https://github.com/maxogden/concat-stream) that causes [module-deps](https://github.com/substack/module-deps) to throw when a transform returns an empty string. I submitted https://github.com/maxogden/concat-stream/pull/23 to fix the issue.

This is routinely happening to me when I have an empty file and a transform simply returns a passthrough stream.

The specific error is this:

title: Feature request: Avoid loading linked modules multiple times
body:
We run into the following issue with quite a large dependency tree:

When linking packages with `npm link` that share a dependency, Browserify loads the module twice because they are in different paths. This leads to various problems from multiple socket connections to `instanceof` not working anymore.

It would be great if Browserify could consider the package.json's name / version to detect this case.

Thanks!

title: Browserify as a NodeJS app packager/uglifier
body:
I was looking for a way to "secure" NodeJS source files (basically a NodeApp running in stores on some removable media), wondered if somehow this might be possible with browserify?

I'm looking to concat any required local files then uglify the whole to end up with a single script to start my whole app (npm packages should not be included). Could be a nice addition to the project (looks like it would require to deactivate some features), maybe with flags, like `--target-node --uglify`?

Thanks!

title: Remove Tarball Dependency
body:
- Add new querystring-es3 node module
- Update exports to use new package

Closes #683

title: Please publish `querystring` IE8 branch to npm
body:
#### Issue

Do you think it would be possible to publish your IE8/ES3-compatible branch of the `querystring` npm package to the npm registry as something like `querystring-ie8` or (as suggested in https://github.com/Gozala/querystring/pull/5) `querystring-es3`?  This would allow the removal of the GH link from https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/package.json#L53 .
#### Rationale

Our team, and many others, run a private npm registry that replicates from the public npm registry.  This allows us to operate during npm and GitHub outages.  Because browserify is a core part of our build system (awesome), a GitHub outage would totally hose us due to this one GH tarball dependency (not awesome).  I also noticed that the GH tarball doesn't get cached, so even that couldn't save us.
#### Related
- https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/652

title: Source maps not working with Firefox
body:
Firefox has partial support for source maps. The Console tab doesn't use them yet, but ClojureScript's source maps are working fine for me in the Debugger tab. Browserify's do not.

The issue seems to be full pathnames in the source map's "sources" key:

``` .js
    "sources": [
        "/home/graue/code/projectname/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-pack/_prelude.js",
        "/home/graue/code/projectname/node_modules/backbone/backbone.js",
        "/home/graue/code/projectname/node_modules/bean/bean.js",
        "/home/graue/code/projectname/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/buffer/index.js",
        "/home/graue/code/projectname/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/buffer/node_modules/base64-js/lib/b64.js",
        "/home/graue/code/projectname/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/buffer/node_modules/ieee754/index.js",
        ...
    ]
```

If I remove the beginnings of each path so all the pathnames are relative to the project root, e.g.

``` .js
        "node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-pack/_prelude.js",
        "node_modules/backbone/backbone.js",
```

then base64-encode the modified source map and stick it back into the Browserify bundle, Firefox's debugger is happy (and Chrome's still is, too).

I've done this manually but may be able to work on a PR for this later, if making Browserify use relative paths is seen as an acceptable change and the best way to go here. Let me know if that sounds like a good plan.

title: Calling `require(13)` results in un-catchable exceptions
body:
Trying to browserify a file that looks like:

``` js
require(13);
```

results in:

```
TypeError: Object 13 has no method 'match'
    at resolve (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:29:11)
    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/index.js:153:20
    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/index.js:71:24
    at fs.js:266:14
    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:107:15)
```

The issue is that this is not passed to any of the callbacks.  It cannot be properly caught.  I'm posting here as I'm not sure where exactly you want the fix to go (resolve, browser-resolve or somewhere else).

title: Feature: strip cwd from hash (Issue #517)
body:
Following on from issue #517, the hashing process (for ids) now strips out cwd before hashing.

For me, this allows me to work with a number of contributors (with different OSs, usernames and project paths) to generate browserified bundles that communicate correctly with consistent hashes.

title: Add fullPaths option.
body:
Completely preserves the original module ids, instead of converting them to numerical indices. Useful for analysing a bundle after it's created, making the browser-unpack module a viable standard approach for picking apart bundle contents.

I suspect there might be some overlap with `opts.commondir` â but I'm unsure if that option still alters the bundle output.

Looking at making [disc](http://github.com/hughsk/disc) a little more future-proof by using browser-unpack, and need this option available to determine the file tree. Thanks! :)

title: Requiring dependencies which have package.json but were not loaded via NPM
body:
As discussed here:
https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim/issues/30

Browserify appears to become confused when a project requires a dependency which has a package.json file and uses "require" but was not installed via NPM

In this case the dependancies are being installed with Bower

I believe the fix would be to fallback to the main projects package.json file if the dependency lacks a "browser" property.

So in this case when Ember.js requires jQuery Browserify should check the the ./bower_components/ember/package.json for a "browser" property. If it exists then the current behavior is correct and it should attempt to load ./bower_components/ember/node_modules/jquery

But if the property is not found as is the case here it should look in ./package.json to resolve the jquery dependency. In this case browersify-shim would then load ./bower_components/jquery as it normally would for a `require('jquery');` in the main project

title: no-builtins: Exclude all builtins from node core
body: Currently --no-builtins only excludes those builtins defined in ./lib/builtins - this doesn't work when I want to browserify some node code using tls (to get code coverage working using coverify)

title: Quotation mark in regexp stops checking file
body:
Hi,

It looks like quotation mark (`"`) put in regular expression stops finding `regular` expressions.

---

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Create a temporary file with `.js` extension and copy this code

``` javascript
/"/, require('assert');
```
1. Run `browserify`on the file with no options.

**Result**
Temporary file in bundle with no dependencies.

**Expected result**
Bundle file with included `assert` module.

title: Module/package size statistics
body:
This is essential for deployment in browser. Everyone wants the bundled script to be as small as possible. To achieve this, one has to know how many bytes are added to the bundle by each module/package.

I propose a new command line argument, for specifying output path for newly created artifact, containing map of file-name to file-size, in JSON format. Next is a simple command line tool that displays this file, groups modules by packages and displays file sizes.

This will allow developers to locate greedy dependencies, replace them by lightweight alternatives and optimize bundle's resulting file size. I went through the source but I couldn't figure out a place to implement this, any hints?

title: Build files too big because of dependencies of dependencies
body:
I'm using npm scripts to build my pages, like so :

``` javascript
{
    "build-common": "browserify -r react/addons -r domready -o build/common.js",
    "build-index": "browserify -x react/addons -x domready pages/index.js -o build/index.js",
    "build-somepage": "browserify -x react/addons -x domready pages/somepage.js -o build/somepage.js",
    "build-js": "npm run build-common && npm run build-index && npm run build-somepage"
}
```

The problem is that all build files contains (almost) everything and weigh more that 500KB. To be precise, the "react/addons" and "domready" modules are properly excluded from the build files, but they all contain all dependencies of React. As the "react/addons" file only contains "module.exports = require('./lib/ReactWithAddons');", this is the only code of React that is factored out in the build/common.js file. The factor-bundle properly bundle all dependencies in the build/common.js file but because of the issue linked above I can't use it.

Note: I'm using the latest React (0.9.0-rc1), the latest Browserify (3.30.1) and tried the latest factor-bundle (0.2.2).

Am I doing something wrong ? I'd really love some help on this one.

title: detectGlobals: true expose full system paths
use buffer@~2.1.4 for utf16 fixes
body: merge https://github.com/substack/insert-module-globals/pull/30 simultaneously

title: --insert-globals option doesn't work
body:
This issue doesn't break anything because globals are inserted anyway if they are found in source code. Also, detecting globals are now very fast thanks to `mine`.

However, cli's `--insert-globals` option doesn't seem to be working. It fails as follows:
1. `browserify --insert-globals=true foo.js`
2. `bundle()`'s `insertGlobals` option becomes a string `"true"`.
3. `insert-module-globals` module gets the string `"true"` as `always` option.
4. It strictly compares the string `"true"` against the boolean `true` and doesn't insert globals.

https://github.com/substack/insert-module-globals/blob/34e5fb7167b858b13ffcc2c73a7827045f2e478e/index.js#L57

This kind of issues can happen to other options too. I couldn't figure out where the _right_ place to fix is, so just opening this issue.

title: exclude using patterns
body:
this is a feature request,
I want to exclude from my bundle all files in /vendor or /external
so instead of indicating the files individually I would like to specify a pattern, eg: "/vendor/*"

title: How to deal with optional dependencies ?
body:
I'm using Backbone & Backbone.native (as a jQuery replacement).
But with browserify, I'm having an issue [just here](https://github.com/jashkenas/backbone/blob/6ccc1583e7f27098f3970143475aab1f9713f341/backbone.js#L21)

`try { $ = require('jquery'); } catch(e) {}`

I don't want jQuery, so for now I just use this really dirty workaround:

```
mkdir ./node_modules/jquery && ln -s ../backbone.native/backbone.native.js ./node_modules/jquery/index.js
```

Any idea how to handle that ?

title: Use npm version of querystring in package.json
body:
In package.json, it's currently `"querystring": "https://github.com/substack/querystring/archive/0.2.0-ie8.tar.gz"`. querystring is on npm. Why not using the npm version ? Does this version not exist in npm ?

For my current project it's a problem because we're behind a f****\* enterprise proxy and it's not easy to bypass. Using the npm version would make npm call the npm registry with http, so no more problem.
